metadata.title: Journal Pre-proof Molecular characterization of SARS-CoV-2 from the first case of COVID-19 in Italy

body_text.text: To the Editor, 19 On January 29, 2020, two Chinese spouses (patient 1, female; patient 2, male), coming to Italy as 20 tourists from Hubei province, were hospitalized at the National Institute for Infectious Diseases "L.

Spallanzani", Rome, with fever and respiratory symptoms. SARS-CoV-2 diagnosis was 22 accomplished using Real Time RT-PCR published method [1] on nasopharyngeal swab and sputum 23 for patient 1 and on nasopharyngeal swab for patient 2, collected one day after symptoms onset.
Partial sequencing confirmed both patients to be infected with SARS-CoV-2.

The number of SARS-CoV-2 reads obtained varied from 4,079 to >14 x 10 6 . By using de novo 37 assembly, two contigs of 29,867 nt (mean coverage: 81,324 reads; range: 26-510,718 reads), and 38 29,792 nt (mean coverage: 80 reads; range: 5-599 reads) were obtained for the isolate and clinical 39 sample of patient 1, respectively, and referred to as consensus sequences. Further analysis was 40 dedicated to identify the variants present at any nucleotide position for the variability analysis.
Considering the consensus sequences, two non-synonymous changes with respect to the Wuhan-

FIGREF0.text: Molecular characterization of SARS-CoV-2 from the first case of COVID-E.M. Gruber, Laboratory of Virology, INMI Lazzaro Spallanzani IRCCS, via Portuense 292, 12 00149 Roma, Italy; email: cesare.gruber@inmi.it; Tel: +390655170668; Fax: +39065594555.

FIGREF2.text: Virus isolate was obtained in Vero E6 cell line from the sputum of patient 1, with cytopatic effect 26 (CPE) evident after 24 hours post-inoculation. At the time of writing, virus isolation from the 27 nasopharyngeal swab sample collected from patient 2 was not successful, likely due to the lower 28 viral load (higher cycle threshold value, 24.56 in the Real Time RT-PCR), therefore no further 29 analysis was performed on the virus detected in patient 2. NGS was performed on the respiratory 30 samples from patient 1 and on the primary isolate, prior to any further passage, by using Ion Torrent 31 S5 platform (Thermofisher). The mean count of sequencing reads obtained per sample was 44 32 million (Min 41.6 x 10 6 -Max 49.7 x 10 6 ). The reads from the two respiratory samples of patient 1 33 were merged to obtain a better coverage along virus genome, and along the paper are referred to as 34 data from the clinical sample. Details of sequencing and bioinformatic analyses are available upon 35 request.

FIGREF3.text: A2269T) was detected in the isolate but not in the corresponding clinical sample. All variants were 46 confirmed by Sanger Sequencing.47    Considering the analysis of genomic variability, several intra-sample variants were observed in both 48 the isolate and the clinical sample, but only the positions with a minimum coverage of 20 reads 49 were considered. Intra-sample assessment of overall virus genome variability resulted 1.27 x10 -4 50 and 1.02x10 -4 nucleotide substitutions per site for the isolate and the clinical sample, respectively.51Only two variable positions were observed with a frequency >10% in the clinical sample, both in 52 Orf1a: A2269T (13.73%, coverage: 51x), synonymous for amino acid A668, and G7388A (13.21%, 53 coverage: 53x), leading to amino acid change (A2375T). Interestingly, the frequency of variants at 54 position 2269 was different in the isolate, being T dominant over A in 72% of reads (coverage: 55 119582x), accounting for the difference resulting in the consensus sequences.56For the phylogenetic analysis, 87 full genome SARS-CoV-2 sequences were retrieved from 57 GISAID, along with WH-01_MN908947.3 from Gen Bank. The G26145T substitution observed in 58 the isolate from Italy was also present in 5 sequences from cases occurring out of China: 59 EPI_ISL_406596 and EPI_ISL_406597 from France, EPI_ISL_406031 from Taiwan, 60 EPI_ISL_406036 from USA, EPI_ISL_406844 and EPI_ISL_408977 from Australia. All the 61 genomes carrying this mutation are included in a significant phylogenetic cluster (bootstrap 87%),62 suggesting common origin (Figure 1a/b); in fact, the G251V substitution in Orf3a has been recently 63 defined as the marker variant of the "V" clade (GISAID). 64 The presence of quasispecies has previously been reported for SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV [3,4], 65 suggesting that these beta coronaviruses may consist of complex and dynamic distributions of 66 closely related variants in vivo, similar to other RNA viruses. When applied to SARS-CoV-2 in this 67 study, the analysis of sequence variability supported the presence of viral quasispecies in the clinical sample as well as in the primary isolate. Namely, two positions with variant frequency 69 >10% were observed in the biological sample, both in Orf1a: A2269T, synonymous, and G7388A, 70 corresponding to aminoacid change A2375T. The synonymous variant A2269T, representing a 71 minority variant in the clinical sample, was the dominant one in the isolate. Although low coverage 72 may have affected the precise calculation of minority variant frequency in the clinical sample, the 73 data are consistent with variant selection occurred during the isolation procedure, as previously 74 shown for other respiratory viruses. In the respiratory sample neither mutations nor intra-sample 75 variants were found at positions 8,782 and 28,144, recently identified as hotspots of hypervariability 76 (coverage: 61x and 76x respectively) [5]. 77 Full genome characterization of new viruses is instrumental for updating diagnostics and assessing 78 viral evolution. On the other hand, virus variability, leading to the development of quasispecies 79 within infected patients, may provide the background for virus evolution and adaptation to new 80 hosts; more studies are necessary to unravel the importance of intra-patient variability in the SARSstate that there are no relevant conflicts of interest to declare. 85 This research was supported by funds to National Institute for Infectious Diseases 'Lazzaro 86 Spallanzani' IRCCS from: Ministero della Salute, Ricerca Corrente. 87 We gratefully acknowledge the contributors of genome sequences of the newly emerging 88 coronavirus, i.e. the Originating and Submitting Laboratories, for sharing their sequences and other 89 metadata through the GISAID Initiative, on which this research is based.
